articles.headline: The Myth of the Rich Who Flee From Taxes
articles.snippet: Despite what low-tax advocates might say, jobs, cost of housing, family ties and climate tend to be stronger reasons for relocation, according to recent academic studies.
articles.abstract: Despite what low-tax advocates might say, jobs, cost of housing, family ties and climate tend to be stronger reasons for relocation, according to recent academic studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Vladimir V. Putin hugged his newly minted fellow Russian citizen, the actor Gerard Depardieu, posing for cameras at the Black Sea port of Sochi. “I adore your country,” Mr. Depardieu gushed — especially its 13 percent flat tax on personal income.

articles.headline: Farmer’s Supreme Court Challenge Puts Monsanto Patents at Risk
articles.snippet: An Indiana farmer will face off on Tuesday against the world’s largest seed company in a case that could deal a huge blow to the future of genetically modified crops.
articles.abstract: An Indiana farmer will face off on Tuesday against the world’s largest seed company in a case that could deal a huge blow to the future of genetically modified crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his mere 300 acres of soybeans, corn and wheat, Vernon Hugh Bowman said, “I’m not even big enough to be called a farmer.”

articles.headline: Texas Senator Goes on Attack and Raises Bipartisan Hackles
articles.snippet: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, has quickly made his presence felt with brash moves that have raised the hackles of colleagues from both parties.
articles.abstract: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, has quickly made his presence felt with brash moves that have raised the hackles of colleagues from both parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate edged toward a divisive filibuster vote on Chuck Hagel’s nomination to be defense secretary, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, sat silent and satisfied in the corner of the chamber — his voice lost to laryngitis — as he absorbed what he had wrought in his mere seven weeks of Senate service.

articles.headline: SAC Clients Said to Seek $1.7 Billion in Refunds
articles.snippet: The outflows are a blow to the fund founded by Steven A. Cohen, which has one of the best investment track records on Wall Street, but they are expected to have little effect on its business.
articles.abstract: The outflows are a blow to the fund founded by Steven A. Cohen, which has one of the best investment track records on Wall Street, but they are expected to have little effect on its business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clients of SAC Capital Advisors have asked to withdraw $1.7 billion from the giant hedge fund as the government’s insider trading investigation intensifies, according to people briefed on the matter.

articles.headline: Incomes Flat in Recovery, but Not for the 1%
articles.snippet: New data show uneven benefits from the economic recovery of 2010-11, with a big rise for the highest earners and little change for others.
articles.abstract: New data show uneven benefits from the economic recovery of 2010-11, with a big rise for the highest earners and little change for others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Incomes rose more than 11 percent for the top 1 percent of earners during the economic recovery, but not at all for everybody else, according to new data.

articles.headline: In New England, a Natural Gas Trap
articles.snippet: The region’s reliance on natural gas for power generation has collided recently with a surge in demand for heating.
articles.abstract: The region’s reliance on natural gas for power generation has collided recently with a surge in demand for heating.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electricity prices in New England have been four to eight times higher than normal in the last few weeks, as the region’s extreme reliance on natural gas for power supplies has collided with a surge in demand for heating.

articles.headline: Rise of Drones in U.S. Drives Efforts to Limit Police Use
articles.snippet: Drones are becoming a darling of law enforcement officials across the country. But they have prompted  fears of government surveillance, often even before they take to the skies.
articles.abstract: Drones are becoming a darling of law enforcement officials across the country. But they have prompted  fears of government surveillance, often even before they take to the skies.
articles.lead_paragraph: They can record video images and produce heat maps. They can be used to track fleeing criminals, stranded hikers — or just as easily, political protesters. And for strapped police departments, they are more affordable than helicopters.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Faces Fire as It Pulls Out of Afghanistan
articles.snippet: As American troops get ready to speed up their withdrawal, it is clear some of it will happen under fire, as Taliban fighters try to strike in areas where the idea of Afghan-led security remains an abstraction.
articles.abstract: As American troops get ready to speed up their withdrawal, it is clear some of it will happen under fire, as Taliban fighters try to strike in areas where the idea of Afghan-led security remains an abstraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: STRONG POINT HAJI RAHMUDDIN II, Afghanistan — When the last American soldiers to occupy this squat, lonely outpost in southern Afghanistan pulled out this week, they left the same way earlier units had arrived: ready for a fight.

articles.headline: Pope Electors Are Sizing Up a Field of Peers
articles.snippet: The cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic church have been quietly evaluating potential successors for years.
articles.abstract: The cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic church have been quietly evaluating potential successors for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no formal nominating process for choosing the man to succeed Pope Benedict XVI, and campaigning for oneself is counterproductive. But the cardinals who will file into the Sistine Chapel next month to elect a new leader of the Roman Catholic Church have been quietly sizing up potential candidates for years.

articles.headline: The Slugfest in the Executive Suite
articles.snippet: Mixed martial arts has become hugely popular — and lucrative — on television. That is leaving media giants locked in a battle over the future of the sport.
articles.abstract: Mixed martial arts has become hugely popular — and lucrative — on television. That is leaving media giants locked in a battle over the future of the sport.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY

articles.headline: Don’t Blink, or You’ll Miss Another Bailout
articles.snippet: A deal involving Bank of America that came to light recently shows how bank bailouts have continued, even if in a much quieter form than in the depths of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: A deal involving Bank of America that came to light recently shows how bank bailouts have continued, even if in a much quieter form than in the depths of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANY people became rightfully upset about bailouts given to big banks during the mortgage crisis. But it turns out that they are still going on, if more quietly, through the back door.

articles.headline: In China, Families Bet It All on College for Their Children
articles.snippet: Millions of Chinese sacrifice heavily for their children’s education, but as graduates saturate the job market, the security they seek is increasingly elusive.
articles.abstract: Millions of Chinese sacrifice heavily for their children’s education, but as graduates saturate the job market, the security they seek is increasingly elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANJING, China — Wu Yiebing has been going down coal shafts practically every workday of his life, wrestling an electric drill for $500 a month in the choking dust of claustrophobic tunnels, with one goal in mind: paying for his daughter’s education.

articles.headline: Obama’s Plan Sees 8-Year Wait for Illegal Immigrants
articles.snippet: Disclosure of the proposal set off political recriminations and questions on Sunday about President Obama’s promise to allow bipartisan Congressional talks to take precedence.
articles.abstract: Disclosure of the proposal set off political recriminations and questions on Sunday about President Obama’s promise to allow bipartisan Congressional talks to take precedence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A plan by President Obama for an overhaul of the immigration system would put illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship that could begin after about eight years and would require them to go to the back of the line behind legal applicants, according to a draft of the legislation that the White House has circulated in the administration.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Obama Faces Risks in Pipeline Decision
articles.snippet: In deciding whether to approve the Keystone oil pipeline, President Obama faces a choice between alienating environmental advocates or causing a deep rift with Canada.
articles.abstract: In deciding whether to approve the Keystone oil pipeline, President Obama faces a choice between alienating environmental advocates or causing a deep rift with Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama faces a knotty decision in whether to approve the much-delayed Keystone oil pipeline: a choice between alienating environmental advocates who overwhelmingly supported his candidacy or causing a deep and perhaps lasting rift with Canada.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder, Clifford Krauss and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Logging Off to Trace a Web Photo to Its Source
articles.snippet: A photo of exploding manhole covers in Omaha that took over the Web last month prompted two responses: wonder and skepticism.
articles.abstract: A photo of exploding manhole covers in Omaha that took over the Web last month prompted two responses: wonder and skepticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: When photographs of spontaneous events miraculously appear on the Web, it generally prompts two responses: wonder and skepticism.

articles.headline: Inquiry Into China Film Trade Unnerves Hollywood
articles.snippet: A chill between Hollywood and China remains almost a year after word leaked about an S.E.C. investigation into possible corrupt practices.
articles.abstract: A chill between Hollywood and China remains almost a year after word leaked about an S.E.C. investigation into possible corrupt practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hunkered down. Lawyered up. Looking over your shoulder for the prosecutors.

articles.headline: ‘Fast & Furious’ Stresses Social Side of Fandom
articles.snippet: Universal’s “Fast & Furious” series is a second-class citizen in Hollywood, but not online, where it has more Facebook “likes” than any active film series except “Avatar.”
articles.abstract: Universal’s “Fast & Furious” series is a second-class citizen in Hollywood, but not online, where it has more Facebook “likes” than any active film series except “Avatar.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Despite selling $1.8 billion in tickets, Universal’s “Fast & Furious” car-racing series is Hollywood’s equivalent of a second-class citizen.

articles.headline: A Matter of Perception
articles.snippet: Using low-cost components developed for mobile devices, a start-up called Oculus VR hopes to put a high-quality virtual reality headset within reach of video gamers.
articles.abstract: Using low-cost components developed for mobile devices, a start-up called Oculus VR hopes to put a high-quality virtual reality headset within reach of video gamers.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — Virtual reality is one of many inventions that never seemed to make the leap from science fiction to mass-market product.

articles.headline: Tech Industry Sets Its Sights on Gambling
articles.snippet: With some states poised to clear the way for legal gambling on the Internet, Silicon Valley’s traditional gaming companies are expanding to meet the expected deluge of players.
articles.abstract: With some states poised to clear the way for legal gambling on the Internet, Silicon Valley’s traditional gaming companies are expanding to meet the expected deluge of players.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Look out Las Vegas, here comes FarmVille.

articles.headline: In Kabul’s ‘Car Guantánamo,’ Autos Languish and Trust Dies
articles.snippet: Behind high stone walls are thousands of cars, trucks, vans, motorcycles and even bicycles, lined up in vehicular purgatory after falling afoul of the Kabul traffic police.
articles.abstract: Behind high stone walls are thousands of cars, trucks, vans, motorcycles and even bicycles, lined up in vehicular purgatory after falling afoul of the Kabul traffic police.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — On the northern edge of Kabul, down a road riddled with mammoth potholes, is a secure site that bears all the marks of a prison: high stone walls topped with concertina wire, police officers barking into walkie-talkies, forsaken visitors pacing the compound’s edge, waiting for a sign of hope.

articles.headline: Voting Rights Act Is Challenged as Cure the South Has Outgrown
articles.snippet: An Alabama county contends that a main provision of the law that requires it to get permission before making changes that affect voting, has outlived its purpose of protecting minorities.
articles.abstract: An Alabama county contends that a main provision of the law that requires it to get permission before making changes that affect voting, has outlived its purpose of protecting minorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERGREEN, Ala. — Jerome Gray, a 74-year-old black man, has voted in every election since 1974 in this verdant little outpost of some 4,000 people halfway between Mobile and Montgomery. Casting a ballot, he said, is a way to honor the legacy of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, a civil rights landmark born from a bloody confrontation 70 miles north of here, in Selma.

articles.headline: Russians Wade Into the Snow to Seek Treasure From the Sky
articles.snippet: On Friday, terror rained from the skies in Siberia, but by Monday, what fell from the sky had turned to gold for people who rushed to retrieve meteorite fragments.
articles.abstract: On Friday, terror rained from the skies in Siberia, but by Monday, what fell from the sky had turned to gold for people who rushed to retrieve meteorite fragments.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEPUTATSKOYE, Russia — Ever since the meteor exploded somewhere over this impoverished Siberian town, Larisa V. Briyukova wondered what to do with the fist-size stone she found under a hole in the roof tiles of her woodshed.

articles.headline: Chávez Returns to Venezuela, Trailing Doubts
articles.snippet: The predawn homecoming of President Hugo Chávez more than two months after having cancer surgery did little to dispel the uncertainty over who was running the country.
articles.abstract: The predawn homecoming of President Hugo Chávez more than two months after having cancer surgery did little to dispel the uncertainty over who was running the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In a surprise predawn homecoming, President Hugo Chávez returned to Venezuela on Monday more than two months after having cancer surgery in Cuba, potentially clearing up some of the legal questions that have roiled the nation during his long absence but doing little to dispel the deep uncertainty over who is running the country.
